title: Thursday, 4th August, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Hiya

PM

This is Markets Live, where we try and fill in the gap between now and the Bank of England news at 12

PM

Actually, you'll need to do a test

11:02 am
PM

PM

Click this link: http://streamstudi...am=flash-video-500

PM

If you can see the test playback, you're all set

11:03 am
PM

For the 12.30 press conference, that is.

PM

What do you reckon we'll get?

PM

I really don't have a firm sense

11:04 am
BE

We'll get a rate cut, surely. That's, what, 98% certainty now?

PM

I don't know.

PM

Anyway, we'll see in just under an hour's time.

11:05 am
undefined
PM

Before we get going properly, can I just mention Avanti?

BE

You can.

11:05 am
PM

Price is moving now

Avanti Communications Group PLC (AVN:LSE): Last: 22.50, no change, High: 22.50, Low: 22.00, Volume: 73.32k
PM

LIve is 28.3p

11:05 am
PM

Up 23%

BE

Dunno why. Inmarsat's boxed out for six months.

PM

Which is because of this: http://ftalphavill...rawing-last-month/

11:06 am
PM

Kleinman was right when he said last week that Inmarsat had approached Avanti

PM

In fact they table two offers

PM

The second one was something approaching 150p a share

11:07 am
BE

(Indicative, non binding ones.)

PM

Yeah, indicative

PM

Were they just trying to get in the Avanti data room?

11:07 am
PM

Or was this for real, do you reckon?

BE

The data room angle was my first thought. Act very nice during a semi-public sale process, take a poke around, then go away again.

BE

But I still struggle with the idea of any company digesting Avanti's debt willingly, and I know that's where our perspectives differ.

11:09 am
PM

Think it has about £500m of debt

PM

Which is tough to swallow, for any one

PM

But they've clearly got the backing of this Boston lot, Mast Capital

11:10 am
PM

We'll see how it pans out

BE

Hm ...... Having been party to the same information as you PM, the theoretical offer price does look absolutely extraordinary. I'm just not sure how to read that.

BE

.... but anyway, we should mention Inmarsat results. Since we're here.

11:11 am
PM

Yes we should

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 828.50, up 48 (+6.15%), High: 848.00, Low: 779.50, Volume: 2.29m
BE

And they're decent. No sign of the glut of bandwidth we've been talking about for quite a while, which (as we've also been talking about for quite a while) only overlaps Inmarsat's spectrum at the edges.

11:12 am
BE

So, Q2 ahead, guidance reiterated, some new deals signed.

BE

Some improvement in the Maritime side, which might indicate a bottom there.

BE

Credit Suisse incoming.

11:14 am
BE

Inmarsat has reported a solid Q2 with (1) revenue in line with consensus;
(2) a sequential improvement in yoy Maritime revenue trends; and (3) all
financial (revenue, CAPEX & Ligado) guidance reiterated. Furthermore,
Inmarsat has announced another 2 new long-term contracts that we believe
further underpin the company's strong 3-5 year revenue growth outlook.

BE

Q216 revenue (ex-Ligado) of $295m was in line with consensus driven
by an improvement in Maritime (-0.5% yoy in Q2 vs. -5% in Q1), a 2% beat in
Government (+2% yoy in Q2) and a 2% beat in Enterprise (-5% yoy in Q216)
offset by a miss in Aviation (although still growing over 8% yoy). Within this
Q2 MSS (higher-margin traffic) revenue was up 9% yoy vs. up 4% in Q1.
EBITDA (ex-Ligado) was 12% ahead of consensus with, on our calculation,
around half of the beat driven by favourable net currency movements.

BE

2018 revenue guidance reiterated. Inmarsat is reiterating its guidance of
FY2018 Group revenues (excluding any benefit from Ligado) of between
$1,450-1,600m. Taking the mid-point of this FY2018 guidance of $1,525m,
this is now mechanically ~6% ahead of consensus ($1,443m).

11:14 am
BE

Inmarsat signs third substantial Maritime Global Xpress (GX) deal.
Inmarsat has signed another major Maritime GX deal with Navarino, one of
the largest maritime VSAT sellers. Together with the recently signed deals
with Marlink and SpeedCast this amounts to a total commitment of greater than 5,000
Fleet Xpress installations over the next 5 years. As we stated on 13 June we
believe these deals are a strong early endorsement of Global Xpress

BE

Inmarsat announces 5-year contract award from US Navy (the "CSSC"
contract). Inmarsat has confirmed the award of the US Navy's next
generation commercial satellite communications contract (also known as
"CSSC"). This contract is expected to run until the end of 2021.

BE

Interim dividend of $20.6c (+5% yoy) with new scrip dividend election

11:15 am
PM

On the Aviation side, I can't see any mention of this Europasat/HellasSat-3 thing

PM

Some people saying it's been delayed -- cos of SpaceX launch problems

PM

Not problems building the actual satellite

11:16 am
PM

Oh no, now you've got me reading Space News

PM

http://spacenews.c...broadband-service/

PM

PARIS – Mobile satellite services provider Inmarsat is all but certain to miss a European regulatory deadline for its satellite-terrestrial aeronautical broadband service, raising the possibility that one or more governments could revoke Inmarsat’s rights to the radio spectrum, industry officials said.

Inmarsat said the Europasat/HellasSat-3 satellite, co-owned by Inmarsat and fleet operator Arabsat of Saudi Arabia and built by Thales Alenia Space of France and Italy, has met its construction milestones but is facing delays at launch-service provider SpaceX of Hawthorne, California.

- See more at: http://spacenews.c...hash.8JQw8kpg.dpuf

11:17 am
PM

t remains unclear when the satellite will be launched, but it will be well after the Dec. 1 deadline imposed by its license and may not occur before mid-2017. - See more at: http://spacenews.c...hash.8JQw8kpg.dpuf

BE

Fair enough. It's a fascinating time in satellites.

BE

I'm not against the idea that the Eutelsat profit warning was an Eutelsat issue and the glut of HTS won't necessarily trash all the legacy markets. But I'm not entirely believing it either.

11:18 am
undefined
BE

And so, to drugs.

Hikma Pharmaceuticals PLC (HIK:LSE): Last: 2,308, down 360 (-13.49%), High: 2,407, Low: 2,212, Volume: 1.40m
11:19 am
BE

Profit warning, on the tape post the close yesterday.

BE

US generics the problem.

BE

Raising some concerns about the Roxane acquisition, I'd have thought, which you'll remember also had to warn during the deal completion.

11:20 am
PM

hmm

BE

So. Today's warning is slower than anticipated new drug approvals and the phasing of litigation costs.

BE

No detail on which products.

11:21 am
BE

Here's Citi to summarise where we are.

BE

While guidance for Branded/Injectables (90% of group EBIT) has been reiterated/raised we cut 2016E core EBIT/EPS -9% to $367m/$1.08 (cons $420m/$1.22), with -2-5% EPS downgrades from 2017E (FX an incremental headwind). Roxane guidance for 2017 reiterated; $700-750m revenues on back of pipeline launches with a medium term EBITDA margin 35%.

BE

Developments at US Generics at best can be described as a ‘short term hiccup’. At worse, sentiment concerns around the revenue/margin potential from the Roxane pipeline will increase, which is not helped by the lack of clarity on the pipeline given commercial sensitivities until 2017. Importantly, there have been no issues with rebates or wholesaler chargebacks. We continue to be at the bottom-end of US revenue guidance for 2016/17 to reflect regulatory risks/product delays. Despite the potential launch of generic Advair in May (2016e branded sales $2bn) we forecast 2017e Roxane pipeline sales of just $135m, rising to a peak of $800m in 2022, with the Roxane EBIT margin rising from 3.5% in 2016e to 20-40%.

11:22 am
BE

The shares are up 50% since falling to their low for the year in March and have now reached our target price. While we continue to like the long-term fundamentals, it is difficult to justify raising our target price given EPS estimate cuts and a 2017E PE of 24x. Consequently we downgrade to Neutral. Our NPV valuation is £29 (WACC 8%, g=2%, $/£ of 1.32) with a bull-bear spread of £40-18, which does not assume further utilisation of the balance sheet. Hikma offers an 18% 5YR EPS CAGR from 2017, though cutting our Roxane pipeline estimates in half would lead to -15-20% EPS downgrades.

BE

Seems odd to me that no-one who works towards the news pages newspapers has ever taken a look at Hikma, given its rather aggressive model.

PM

You are right that it gets very little coverage

11:24 am
BE

Use shortages of generics to price gouge seems to be a tricky old business. As in the doxycycline thing a few years back. https://next.ft.co...-a0c0-00144feabdc0

PM

Sheesh

BE

And the Roxane purchase gives it another 84 products, including quite important ones like Advair.

11:25 am
BE

But we're covering old ground here, which some analysts (and I'm sure the company feltcollaredsource s) see as legacy.

BE

Here's Barclays.

BE

Key takeaways from the conference call

· The company notes slower approval rates for West-Ward products were due to FDA timing and not due to issues with filings.

· West-Ward Columbus mid-term EBITDA margin target remains at 35% with the timing to achieve this unchanged. Cost savings are still expected in the range of $35-$45m by the end of 2017.

· With regards to whether a reliance on the pipeline for 2017 is now increased and the potential impact of slower approval rates on 2017, the company says their forecast for West-Ward Columbus in 2017 is unchanged.

· The company notes that the outlook for colchicine remains unchanged, following Express Scripts’ (ESRX) decision to exclude generic colchicine (competitor generics were excluded as well) from its formulary list with Hikma’s branded colchicine (Mitigare) and Takeda’s Colcrys as preferred. In our view, whilst ESRX’s decision is a positive for Mitigare, a product Hikma invested heavily to promote, the overall impact on the combined branded and generic colchicine is unclear as we do not know what the implied change in net price was to get preference, coupled with the exclusion of Hikma’s own generic colchicine.

11:26 am
BE

West-Ward Columbus is the new name for Roxane, in case you're wondering.

undefined
PM

All the oilers are up

11:27 am
PM

And yet the Footsie is down (a bit)

PM

How do you explain that Bryce, eh?

PM

Actually, oilers are mixed. I correct myself

11:28 am
BE

Do I have to? I mean, Shell's been kicked around quite a lot post results (which were terrible).

Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 1,950, up 44.5 (+2.34%), High: 1,958, Low: 1,922, Volume: 2.90m
BE

I'd suggest that's due a rebound, as the divi's probably safe? Right?

11:29 am
BE

Whether its non-junk credit rating's safe is another matter, and a downgrade would be tricky for the LNG trading side.

BE

As per Glencore last year. Albeit on a smaller scale, clearly.

undefined
11:31 am
PM

Half an hour till BoE ac tion

PM

Or inaction

PM

Actually RBC have a handy guide to impact on the banks

11:31 am
PM

Of various policy moves

PM

Let me share

BE

A theme that's getting a lot of splashy press coverage at the moment .....

11:32 am
PM

Guidance from banks so far on the impact of a 25bps rate cut
Banks have given various pieces of guidance on the impact of rate cuts through the H1 results. The most bearish guidance is CYBG and the most optimistic guidance is BARC (note RBS reports on Friday)

PM

LLOY maintain their margin guidance of 2.7% NIM in the event of a rate cut. H1 was 2.74% so LLOY has built in a buffer here. Over the next 12 months the impact of a 25bps rate cut is something like £100m according to the company- about 0.9% of NII and 1.2% of underlying pre tax
· BARC maintain that their margin will be stable at the Q2 level in the event of a 25bps rate cut. Asset spread compression will be offset with liability repricing with a slight time lag.
· HSBC guide to c.$200m negative impact from a 25bps rate cut which is 0.7% of group NII and 1% of PBT
· CYBG estimates a £10-15m hit to 2017 NII from a 25bps rate cut equivalent to 1.2-1.8% of NII and 5-8% of pre tax.

PM

Rate cut
Least painful for LLOY, more so for RBS, BARC and CYBG.

11:33 am
PM

· As we highlighted in our recent sector note, banks with a large proportion of non interest bearing current account funding see more rate compression in a low rate environment than others. LLOY has 10% of funding from this source; RBS and BARC greater than 20%; CYBG 7%.
· Also in our note, we show that UK banks that use receive variable rate interest rate swaps to hedge interest rate exposure and swap rates are already falling. We prefer banks with a smaller hedge. CYBG hedge is 28% of assets; RBS has 20%; BARC 14%; LLOY 14% (LLOY surprised the market with a larger than expected hedge at results).
· Challenger banks naturally have more variable rate exposure due to their focus on BTL loans (which are 60-70% variable rate much higher than owner occupier mortgages). Aldemore for example has 48% floating rate assets; OSB c.68% mortgages are variable rate. CYBG is lower as a more diversified bank at 23% of mortgages. LLOY has 1/3 of its mortgages directly linked to base rates. BARC has 37% of mortgages in the tracker portfolio.

PM

Funding For Lending expansion
Likely most beneficial for LLOY. RBS, BARC and CYBG have not used FLS in the past- they have not had access due to non core run off portfolios leading to negative loan growth (need positive loan growth to use the FLS).

PM

Currently, the rate of FLS funds is 0.25%. That offers a modest benefit for banks in comparison to other sources of funding. Realistically the rate will have to come down or linked to base rate if that falls as well. This should help banks by providing cheaper funding- to which LLOY has more access.
· Currently the FLS gives 5 times the amount of net lending growth to SMEs only. Historically it has incorporated corporates and mortgages as well (at a 1 times multiple) and access could be widened by increasing the scope to other products. RBS and BARC are the large corporate banks- LLOY and CYBG have heavier weights in mortgages.
· Clearly the amount of FLS funding can be increased by increasing the multiple as per above so banks have more potential access.
· The rate could be restructured so that banks which are shrinking have access to FLS funds at sub market rates as well. This has been done by the ECB. In this scenario it would be beneficial for RBS, BARC and CYBG the most.

11:33 am
PM

And QE?

PM

Likely more beneficial for BARC.

PM

· Investment banks typically outperform retail banks through QE periods for two reasons- higher bond valuations and increased bond issuance.
· BARC has 10% of its assets in sovereign exposures compared to 7% at LLOY and 5% at RBS.
· Whether issuance actually increases is uncertain and likely to be driven by confidence as much as QE.

11:34 am
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 149.80, up 1.5 (+1.01%), High: 151.40, Low: 148.20, Volume: 15.09m
Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 53.42, up 0.43 (+0.81%), High: 53.85, Low: 53.03, Volume: 39.51m
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 192.30, up 1.7 (+0.89%), High: 193.50, Low: 189.00, Volume: 3.54m
11:34 am
CYBG PLC (CYBG:LSE): Last: 260.70, up 0.6 (+0.23%), High: 261.20, Low: 257.00, Volume: 454.31k
undefined
BE

(@fjp73: the common sense, I think, is that a majority of shareholders demand a divi more than they demand management to deliver on a gearing ratio of below three. So, the divi gets paid even when it's not covered, until it absolutely can't.)

11:36 am
BE

Oh, on banks, should mention Merrill double upgrade of HSBC this morning.

HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 513.40, up 9 (+1.78%), High: 517.00, Low: 503.85, Volume: 15.49m
PM

What they saying?

11:36 am
BE

I can't quote directly, but they're going for another $2bn buyback in 2017.

BE

Because HSBC has that much spare capital it can use it to get rid of its own shareholders, apparently.

BE

There's also some SOTP stuff for the stake in Bank of Communications, for instance, which Merrill reckons could fund another ~$15bn capital return.

11:01 am
PM

Welcome

BE

Target 540p.

BE

And if Merrill had just sent me the damn note this morning,I wouldn't have to summarise it so awkwardly.

11:39 am
undefined
PM

Interims from Aviva mentioned over on the right

PM

The figs were in line i thought

11:40 am
PM

Dividend up

PM

Hmm -- some people big fans of this

PM

Such as Barrie Cornes at Panmure

11:41 am
PM

We view Aviva as a recovery play with
potential for material returns of surplus capital to shareholders in the medium
term. T

BE

Yeah, it's pretty much inline and possibly due a rally on reassuring, unspectacular figures.

PM

Investment view – We view Aviva as a recovery play with the benefits of the Friends
Life capital synergies yet to come. The non-life business is performing well and the
results will benefit from FX. We do not see Brexit as an issue with the only impact
likely to be a change in its Dublin office. Valuation-wise the shares look exceptionally
attractive trading on 2016/7F PE multiples of 7.8X and 7.2x respectively along with a
2016F dividend yield of 6.1%. We consequently maintain our Buy recommendation
and 525p/share target price.

11:41 am
PM

Brexit not an issue

BE

A lot of this is the benefit of Friends Life cost savings, though.

BE

Which are clearly going to peter out. I'm not sure how much that's flattering the current picture.

11:43 am
BE

RBC .......

BE

Growth – a return to inflows
Annualised net inflows at Aviva investors equated to 2.9% for external
clients and 0.9% for the internal assets. Aviva’s flagship AIMS product is
performing well and assets have grown from £3bn to £6.2bn as it begins to
win institutional mandates from peers. For the Life and platform business
net flows were 1.3% of assets - having been negative in the second half
of 2015.
Growth – 10% growth in new business value
In terms of volume the UK business has shrunk with Q2 sales down 11%
however European sales are considerably stronger (+36%). This perhaps
highlights that the attractions of the Friends Life acquisition were the
balance sheet rather than revenue synergies. The UK pensions book has
seen sales grow 3% year on year however these are down 8% since the
4th quarter (the market does not have a lot of seasonality these days). The
value of these sales in Q2 is however higher with UK new business value
up 9% in the UK and 25% in Europe.
Bottom-line earnings – below the line charges persist
While operating profit was £1,325m various charges and deductions have
reduced the actual net profit for the period to £201m. While £318m of
the charge is expected due to acquisition accounting, the below the line
negatives which have been a feature of Aviva’s results in the past have
continued.
Solvency – in line but a strong performance post Brexit
Solvency II ratio of 174%, 3% pts ahead of consensus and 1% pt shy of our
forecast. Aviva had previously said it was operating towards the top end
of 140-180% range and we note this is a strong result given the reduction
in yields post Brexit.

BE

Note that Aviva said a lot of this stuff in the early July update.

11:44 am
BE

Merrill as well. Quoted this time, not paraphrased.

BE

Weakness YTD a particularly attractive buying opportunity Interim results from Aviva were in line with expectations, with operating profit +13%
YoY, operating EPS +1% YoY, DPS +10% YoY and NAV +6% YTD. In line with most of its
composite peer group, the shares have been weak performers YTD, falling c25%. This
makes Aviva the worst performing of the UK insurers. This is despite a sound and
relatively insensitive capital position, a commitment by management to increase
dividends, efficiently manage capital, and continue to restructure the group. We think
the shares offer outstanding value at just over 7x IFRS EPS and more than a 6.5%
dividend yield (both 2017E). Buy, PO 450p.

BE

Ticking the right boxes on capital and dividends Investors should own lower growth insurers for yield and capital security, in our view.

Aviva’s interim results tick these boxes. Aviva’s economic capital ratio has not
materially moved YTD despite market volatility – 174%, which is 3%pts higher than
expected. Further, the 10% increase in the interim dividend affirms our view that
double digit DPS growth is possible over our forecasting period as Aviva moves to a
50% payout ratio.

Operating profits came in at £1,325m (+13% YoY) against our £1,359m forecast and
£1,313m consensus. Operating EPS growth is adversely affected by the higher share
count this year and edged 1% higher YoY at 22.4p. Aviva’s book value benefitted from
favourable Fx moves, growing 6% YTD to close H1 at 412p per share, ahead of our 408p
forecast and consensus of 399p. This includes a number of market related movements
and a pre-emptive £250m charge against the UK commercial real estate book.

11:45 am
BE

(@roddy1234: fair enough. It should be the vegan option, given petrol's made of dinosaurs.)

undefined
PM

My word it's slow for a thursday

11:46 am
PM

But then it's the first thursday in August

PM

Singapore going ahead with their takeover offer fro the Baltic Exchange

PM

The Baltic Exchange Limited (Baltic Exchange) announces that, following agreement with the Singapore Exchange (SGX), it will now proceed with the solicitation of support from Baltic Exchange Shareholders for SGX’s offer to acquire the issued ordinary share capital for GBP 160.41 in cash per Baltic Share. This represents a total consideration of GBP 77.6 million. It is contemplated that the Baltic Shareholders will also receive from the Baltic Exchange a minimum of GBP 18.80 in cash per Baltic Share, as a final dividend, conditional upon the acquisition proceeding. This means that the total valuation of the Baltic Exchange is a minimum of GBP 86.7 million.

The Baltic Exchange will now consult its major shareholders to secure their support for SGX’s offer. Subject to receiving sufficient support, and to it receiving the endorsement of the Baltic Exchange Board, it is expected that a scheme of arrangement will then be circulated to shareholders and a General Meeting will be announced, for shareholders to vote on an offer from SGX.

BE

11:49 am

Johnston Press, for instance.

Johnston Press PLC (JPR:LSE): Last: 11.55, down 2.2 (-16.00%), High: 13.00, Low: 11.00, Volume: 603.25k
BE

BE

People are buying very few newspapers. And if you make those newspapers rubbish, people are even less likely to buy them.

BE

BE

And that's a three-decade low for the shares, I think.

11:52 am
BE

Here's Numis to summarise.

BE

Johnston Press has reported H1 results that have come in a little below our estimates at every level. Outlook comments acknowledge the uncertainty faced post Brexit. Our key issue at Johnston remains debt which has risen to £209m representing almost 4x our annualised EBITDA. This material debt pile, relative to cashflows, in combination with the declining and uncertain trading environment place a significant question mark on the equity value in the business. We place our target, recommendation and forecasts under review ahead of the 9am meeting today.

BE

Four times EBITDA. Cripes.

11:52 am
BE

A tough H1. Revenues £114m (NSe £118m), adjusted operating profit £22m (NSe £24m), adjusted EPS 9.3p (NSe 9.7p) and net debt £209m NSe (£207.5m). The pension deficit has reduced to £23.2m, one small positive.
Classified particularly tough. Revenue trends in the half were disappointing, with digital (ex classified) up just 1.6% of particular note. Print advertising ex classified was down 10.3%. Classified and other advertising down 28.2% in the period. In terms of quarterly trends, whilst it is marginally encouraging to see a little improvement overall from Q1 to Q2 it is worth noting that classified deteriorated from -25.4% to -31.2%.
Outlook uncertain. Outlook comments acknowledge post Brexit uncertainty. In light of this added uncertainty the company is focussed on revenue and cost measures to maintain margins and minimise the impact of the difficult trading environment.
Remain a potential seller of assets. Having announced the intention to sell the Isle of Man operations for £4.25m the Group again confirms that it is actively exploring opportunities for the disposal of further assets.
High level of debt remains a significant issue. All in results are a little low to our estimates, and given increased uncertainty and advertising run rates we expect to cut estimates reasonably sharply in both 2016E and 2017E. The material debt pile remains our key issue at Johnston, in combination with the very tough trading backdrop this places a significant question mark on the equity value in the business.

BE

And Peel Hunt.

BE

JPR’s H1 results are said to be below Board expectations, and
paint a depressing picture. Revenue, £113.9m (-10% yoy);
EBITDA, £25.5m (-13% yoy); Statutory loss, £211.4m; net
debt, £209.4m; net assets, £112m; £3m operating cash flow (vs
£25m, H1 2015). Statements still prepared on a going concern
basis. Outlook mixed, with classifieds described as ‘challenged’.
No new news on asset disposals. Scope for downgrades pending
further company contact. Target price under review. As it
stands, equity is 6% of the EV and, hence, option value only. We
anticipate weakness in the JPR bonds too on deteriorating credit
metrics. As JPR is a re-fi story, this is clearly a concern.

11:54 am
BE

H1 classifieds down 28% yoy.

BE

That's a desperate spiral.

BE

And note .... "The Board is of the opinion … to prepare the financial statements on a going concern basis."

BE

Financial Policy Committee statement and record from its policy meeting, 25 July 2016
04 August 2016
The Bank of England’s Financial Policy Committee (FPC) has decided to exclude central bank reserves from the exposure measure in the current UK leverage ratio framework, with immediate effect.
In doing so, the FPC’s aim is to ensure that the leverage ratio does not act as a barrier to the effective implementation of policy measures that might lead to an increase in central bank reserves. These measures include actions taken to maintain monetary and financial stability since the referendum on the United Kingdom’s membership of the European Union: the package of actions being announced today by the Monetary Policy Committee; and the precautionary step announced by the Bank on 30 June to provide additional flexibility in the Bank’s provision of liquidity insurance by continuing to offer indexed long-term repo operations on a weekly basis until end-September 2016.
The FPC judges that this change to the exposure measure is appropriate because an increase in central bank reserves does not typically expose a firm to additional risks, if matched by liabilities in the same currency: as the ultimate settlement asset, central bank reserves are a unique asset class.
The FPC highlighted in its Financial Stability Report in July that there was a risk of unintended effects from leverage ratio standards on the ability of the banking system to cushion shocks and draw on central bank liquidity facilities as necessary. As a result, it encouraged the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision to review carefully any possible unintended effects of forthcoming leverage ratio standards.

12:09 pm
BE

The FPC is making this improvement to the design of the leverage ratio in the United Kingdom now, given the policy measures being put in place. It recognises that, absent offsetting the impact of this change, excluding current central bank reserves from the exposure measure – the denominator of the leverage ratio – mechanically reduces the nominal amount of capital required to meet the leverage ratio standard, other things equal. This is not the FPC’s intention. It therefore intends to recalibrate the UK leverage ratio standard to offset this impact. It will consult and decide on the appropriate form of this recalibration as part of its planned review of the leverage ratio framework in 2017, in the light of the finalised international standard. In the intervening period, the Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) will monitor firms’ behaviour.
To implement this decision to exclude central bank reserves, the FPC has made the following Recommendation to the PRA: The FPC recommends to the PRA that, when applying its rules on the leverage ratio, it considers allowing firms to exclude from the calculation of the total exposure measure those assets constituting claims on central banks where they are matched by deposits accepted by the firm that are denominated in the same currency and of identical or longer maturity. Central bank claims for these purposes include reserves held by a firm at the central bank, banknotes and coins constituting legal currency in the jurisdiction of the central bank, and assets representing debt claims on the central bank with a maturity of no longer than three months. The FPC made the Recommendation to the PRA on a comply or explain basis.
The FPC has revoked its existing Direction to the PRA on the UK leverage ratio framework, in order to allow the PRA to implement this Recommendation with immediate effect; the FPC’s existing powers of Direction do not enable it to vary the exposure measure used to calculate the leverage ratio. Subject to its 2017 review, the FPC intends to take steps to ensure that the change can be put in place on a permanent basis using its powers of Direction, which will require asking HM Treasury for a change in the relevant statutory instrument to allow variation in the exposure measure.
The PRA is today making a statement on how it is putting this Recommendation into effect.
This announcement does not change the leverage ratio reporting and disclosure requirements that are applicable to UK banks and building societies as set out in the Capital Requirements Regulation (575/2013).

PM

A monetary policy package to support the
UK economy
On 3 August, the MPC voted to introduce a package of
measures to support the economy. This box explains why it
took that action, how those measures will affect output and
inflation and sets out the details of each measure, alongside
other actions taken by the Bank.

PM

Why is the MPC easing policy?
Following the United Kingdom’s vote to leave the
European Union, the exchange rate has fallen and the outlook
for growth in the short to medium term has weakened
markedly. The fall in sterling is likely to push up on CPI
inflation in the near term, hastening its return to the 2%
target and probably causing it to rise above the target in the
latter part of the MPC’s forecast period, before the exchange
rate effect dissipates thereafter. In the real economy,
although the weaker medium-term outlook for activity largely
reflects a downward revision to the economy’s supply
capacity, near-term weakness in demand is likely to open up a
margin of spare capacity, including an eventual rise in
unemployment. Consistent with this, recent surveys of
business activity, confidence and optimism suggest that the
United Kingdom is likely to see little growth in GDP in the
second half of the year.

12:11 pm
PM

These developments present a trade-off for the MPC between
delivering inflation at the target and stabilising activity around
potential. The MPC’s remit requires it to explain how it has
balanced that trade-off. Given the extent of the likely
weakness in demand relative to supply, the MPC judges it
appropriate to provide additional stimulus to the economy,
thereby reducing the amount of spare capacity at the cost of a
temporary period of above-target inflation. Not only will such
action help to eliminate the degree of spare capacity over
time, but because a persistent shortfall in aggregate demand
would pull down on inflation in the medium term, it should
also ensure that inflation does not fall back below the target
beyond the forecast horizon. Thus, in tolerating a temporary
period of above-target inflation, the Committee expects the
eventual return of inflation to the target to be more
sustainable.

PM

The MPC’s August policy decision
The MPC discussed a range of monetary policy tools and the
support each would provide to the economy, and in particular
to UK households and businesses. In an environment of
heightened uncertainty and low interest rates, using a broad
range of tools should increase the effectiveness of the
monetary transmission mechanism, reducing any uncertainty
about the supply and price of credit as well as lowering its cost
and boosting its supply.

PM

On 3 August, the MPC voted to introduce a package of
measures to support the economy:
• A 25 basis point cut in Bank Rate to 0.25%.
• A Term Funding Scheme to reinforce the pass-through of
the cut in Bank Rate, financed by the issuance of central
bank reserves.
• Purchases of a stock of sterling non-financial
investment-grade corporate bonds, issued by firms making
a material contribution to the UK economy, financed by the
issuance of central bank reserves, up to £10 billion.
• An increase in the stock of purchased UK government
bonds, financed by the issuance of central bank reserves, by
£60 billion, to £435 billion.

12:11 pm
PM

The Term Funding Scheme (TFS) will operate as part of the
Asset Purchase Facility (APF). The value of lending in the TFS
will be determined by usage of the scheme, and could reach
around £100 billion. Coupled with the increase in asset
purchases of £70 billion, the total size of the APF could
increase by around £170 billion. The Government indemnifies
the Bank and the APF from any losses arising out of or in
connection with the Facility.
As set out in the August Inflation Report, conditional on this
package of measures, the MPC expects that by the three-year
forecast horizon unemployment will have begun to fall back
and that much of the economy’s spare capacity will have been
absorbed, while inflation will be a little above the 2% target.
In those projections the cumulative growth in output is still
around 2½% less at the end of the forecast period than in the
MPC’s May projections. Much of this reflects a downward
revision to potential supply that monetary policy cannot
offset. However, monetary policy can provide support as the
economy adjusts. Had it not taken the action announced
today, the MPC judges it likely that output would be lower,
unemployment higher and slack greater throughout the
forecast period, jeopardising a sustainable return of inflation
to the target.

PM

This package contains a number of mutually reinforcing
elements, all of which have scope for further action. The MPC
can act further along each of the dimensions of the package by
lowering Bank Rate, by expanding the TFS to reinforce further
the monetary transmission mechanism, and by expanding the
scale or variety of asset purchases. If the incoming data prove
broadly consistent with the August Inflation Report forecast, a
majority of members expect to support a further cut in
Bank Rate to its effective lower bound at one of the MPC’s
forthcoming meetings during the course of this year. The MPC
currently judges this bound to be close to, but a little above,
zero

PM

The Term Funding Scheme
The MPC has launched a Term Funding Scheme.
Purpose: to reinforce the transmission of Bank Rate cuts to those
interest rates actually faced by households and companies.

12:13 pm
PM

The primary objective of the TFS is to reinforce the
pass-through of cuts in Bank Rate to the interest rates faced
by households and companies. In order to achieve this, the
TFS will provide an initial allowance of funding to eligible
institutions (UK banks and building societies that are
participants in the Bank’s Sterling Monetary Framework and
signed up to the Discount Window Facility) that choose to
participate. These institutions will be able to borrow central
bank reserves at close to Bank Rate, for four years, with the
amount they can initially borrow equivalent to 5% of the
stock of their outstanding lending to UK businesses and
households. The lowest cost of funding — Bank Rate — will be
for banks that maintain or expand net lending to the real
economy. In addition to their initial allowance, banks will be
able to access another pound of funding for every pound their
net lending expands between end-June 2016 and
end-December 2017. If their lending shrinks, they will face a
higher fee and receive no additional allowance. For each 1%
that net lending by an institution falls, the cost of TFS funding
will rise by 5 basis points to a maximum of 25 basis points
over Bank Rate (Chart C). The cost of TFS funding is
substantially lower than banks’ current all-in funding costs in
wholesale markets or deposit rates, which average at least
100 basis points

PM

The TFS is a monetary policy instrument. It reinforces the
transmission of Bank Rate cuts and reduces the effective lower
bound toward zero, it charges a penalty rate if banks reduce
net lending, it covers all types of lending, and it is funded by
central bank reserves.
Absent the measures taken by the MPC, projections for
activity in the real economy, and particularly property
markets, would have been consistent with annual growth in
the stock of loans to households and companies of only
around 2% over the coming 18 months, although there is
substantial uncertainty about that projection. The MPC does
not expect the TFS to lead to significantly faster aggregate
loan growth. Rather it should be seen as a mechanism to
prevent any perverse effects on the supply of lending from the
cut in Bank Rate and help ensure that this cut is entirely
passed through to households and companies.
The TFS will have an initial drawdown period of 18 months.
The MPC will confirm by its August 2017 meeting whether the
drawdown period will close at end-February 2018 or be
extended. The MPC could adjust the terms (borrowing
allowance, pricing) and length of the Scheme should
macroeconomic conditions warrant it. However, the terms
and length of the Scheme would not be made less generous by
the MPC during the initial 18 month drawdown window. This
provides the certainty that participants need to form their
initial funding and lending plans. The TFS will operate as part
of the Asset Purchase Facility (APF). The value of lending in
the TFS will be determined by usage of the scheme, and could
reach around £100 billion. Institutions with outstanding
balances in the Bank’s Funding for Lending Scheme (FLS) —
which are charged a fee of 25 basis points to borrow treasury
bills — can refinance those drawings in the TFS, up to their
allowance limit. More details of the scheme are available in a
market notice.(1)
